original_title: Sri Lanka to set up contributory pension fund for state workers
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s cabinet has cleared a proposal by President Ranil Wickremesinghe to prepare a law to set up a contributory pension fund for new state employees, Cabinet Spokesman Minister Bandula Gunawardana said.
The contributory fund will help state workers get a pension without being a burden to the country, Gunawardana said.
The employee will contribute 8 percent and the government will contribute 12 percent to the fund.
At the moment Sri Lanka has a unfunded pension for state workers which is paid for by current tax revenues.
Employees who joined after 2016, can also opt to join the scheme voluntarily, he said.
A contributory pension scheme was proposed in 2002 by the then administration to strenghten state finances but was rejected by the electorate he said.
If the 2004 reforms had been done, Sri Lanka would not have defaulted in 2022, he said. (Colombo/Feb28/2023)
